metadata.title: On effective properties of materials at the nano- and microscales considering surface effects

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
The development of nanotechnologies has recently led to the appearance of newmaterials with very promising physical properties. A reliable understanding of their mechanical properties is by now of crucial importance. The aim of the paper is to discuss material properties of nanostructured materials at the macroscale considering surface/interface properties. Nowadays it is well established that unusual and sometimes very promising properties of nanomaterials relate with surface/interfacial properties. For example, one can observe the socalled size effect, that is dependence of material properties on the size of the considered specimen, see, for example, [18,62], where Young’s modulus of nanobeams made of Ag and Pb is presented; see also [14,47,73].
The author acknowledges the support within the framework of IRSES Project TAMER (PIRSES-GA-2013-610547).
V. A. Eremeyev Otto von Guericke University Magdeburg, Universitätplatz 2, 39106, Magdeburg, Germany
V. A. Eremeyev (B) Southern Scientific Center of RASci and Southern Federal University, Milchakova St. 8a, 344090, Rostov on Don, Russia E-mail: eremeyev.victor@gmail.com Tel.: +49-391-6751843
Unlike in classical mechanics where the size effects can be explained by various mechanisms, such as size of grains and subgrains, dislocations density, microcracks, see, for example, [11], at the nanoscale surface effects are the main reason for them. Nanoobjects, such as nanowires, nanotubes, nanofibers, can be used as working elements of various nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS); see [12,17,31,116,117].
Considering surface properties, we can distinguish perfect and non-perfect surfaces. From themathematical point of view, boundaries of many solids can be modeled as mathematical smooth enough surfaces with additional physical properties. We call such material surfaces perfect. Examples of such material surfaces are surfaces of perfect ZnO nanocrystals and ZnO nanotubes [89].
On the other hand, even in the case of regular objects such as nanocrystals or nanotubes with perfect surfaces, the latter can form thin but very irregular structures, such as a ZnO nanoarray presented in [79,89] (see Fig. 1a, b). Such regular or irregular structures of nanocrystals, nanotubes and nanowires can be obtained by various methods and can be used for producing elements of sensors, actuators, displays and other elements of NEMS as catalysts, etc.; see, for example, [12,42,79,80,106,109]. For example, the modification with broadband omnidirectional antireflection coating of the silicon surface leads to improved properties of solar cells (so-called black silicon) which are very important for green energetics [106].
Besides coatings obtained from regular and sometimes periodical regular objects of simple shape, as shown in Fig. 1a, b, there are more interesting modifications of material surfaces based on highly irregular structures similar to classical cellular or fabricmaterials. Among them there are the so-called self-cleaning and bactericide coatings. The latter are based on recent progresses in the production of superhydrophobic and superoleophobic coatings; see [13,16,19,36,37,48,64,72,94,98,110] and reference therein. Typical structures of self-cleaning polymer coatings are shown in Fig. 1c, d. Such coating can nowadays be applied to relatively rigid material such as glass or metal [36] but also to flexible materials such as textile [19]. Obviously, we cannot call this coating a surface since it has a complex inner structure. On the other hand, keeping in mind that such coatings are very thin in comparison with the size of coated specimens, we call them imperfect surfaces.
The coatings discussed above dramatically change the surface physical properties of the material and the material properties at all. These very promising materials can be called surface metamaterials since their properties are almost determined by inner microstructure and interaction forces acting between elements of the coating.
Obviously, the straightforward modeling of structures shown in Fig. 1b–d is impossible, in general. A detailed description of surface nanostructures is often not possible and even not required, especially if one takes into account the difficulties in determining the properties of micro- and nanosized specimens of the material. This results in the necessity to first study the effective properties of surface-related phenomena and then to use it for the determination of the properties at the macroscale.
Let us briefly discuss the mathematical models and methods used in surface-related mechanics. The origin ofmechanics of surface phenomena relateswith the pioneerworks byLaplace [70,71],Young [121] andPoisson [92] where the surface tension for fluids was introduced and the corresponding boundary-value problems were considered. Later, Gibbs generalized the notion of surface tension in the case of solids [74]. For the recent state of the art in the theory of capillarity one can refer to [39,96]. The model of surface elasticity for elastic solids under large deformations is proposed by Gurtin and Murdoch [45,46]. From the physical point of view, the model can be considered as a nonlinear solid with attached on its surface an elastic membrane. The stressresultant tensor acting in the membrane can be interpreted as surface stresses within the framework of the Gurtin–Murdoch model. As a result, the constitutive equations for bulk and surface behavior are required; thus for the surface elasticitymodel, in addition to the three-dimensional constitutive equations, the two-dimensional constitutive relations are also formulated, where the surface stress tensor depends on the surface strainmeasure. Recently, the Gurtin–Murdoch model found many applications in micro- and nanomechanics [29,56,115]. In particular, the surface effects are used for the explanation of deviation of the properties of nanosized specimens from the ones of bulk materials mentioned above. In other words, the model [46] can predict the size effect observed in the case of nanosized materials [114]. This model is generalized in [107,108] where the bending stiffness of the attached film is taken into account. In [60], it was generalized to thermoelasticity. For further generalizations, we refer to [54,56,91,93,111]. In particular, the model of a Cosserat surface may be useful for material interfaces [97]. Another approach to surface-enhanced models is proposed in [75–78]. Obviously, these extendedmodels of surface elasticity contain additional material parameters which should be determined.
The surface elasticity influences the actual properties of materials [27–30,67,68,115]. It was shown that within the linear theory of surface elasticity the presence of surface stresses leads to the stiffening of the material [3,6,7,33,43,118]. For example, nanoporous materials can be stiffer than non-porous counterparts [30,32]. The increase in the eigenfrequencies for the elastic body with surface stresses, in comparison with the
same body with free boundary, can be also interpreted as the increase in the stiffness [5]. The scaling law for material properties at the nanoscale is proposed in [114]. The presence of surface reinforcements changes the behavior of solutions near singularities in the presence of the imperfect interfaces such as crack ends, holes, notches, points and lines of changing of boundary conditions; see [65,66,84–86,104].
The residual or initial surface stresses also play an important role with respect to thematerial behavior at the nanoscale, in particular changing the free vibrations of materials [44,63,69,112,113]. The finite deformations of elastic solids within the framework of the model [46] together with an analysis of the residual surface stresses are considered in [50–52,122].
Themathematical study of the boundary-value problems of linear elasticitywith surface stresses is provided by various methods in [4,5,57,99] (see also [34]). In particular, the existence of weak solutions is proved in [4], while solvability within terms of classic solutions is studied in [99,105]. Numerical studies with finite element analysis of solids with surface stresses are presented in [55,58,59,61].
Recently, the pure mechanical theory of elasticity with surface stresses was extended for piezoelectric and flexoelectric solids; see [49,90,119,120]. This extension is important since many nanostructured materials exhibit coupling between electromagnetic field and elastic deformations; see, for example, [116,117]. As a result, one can extend classic methods of electroelasticity to construct NEMS [17,31].
We have to mention that other methods of considering surface elasticity are known. Among them we mention ab initio methods and other atomistic simulations; see, for example, [8,20,82,102,103]. Since we focus on the mechanical behavior of surface-enhanced materials, we restrict ourselves to continuum methods referring to discrete models only for comparison of the results. A different model of surface elasticity was introduced in [53]. Here, surface energywas introduced by estimation of excess of bulk energy near the surface. Finally, after the seminal work of Mindlin [83], the surface stresses can be modeled within the framework of the second-gradient and higher-order theories of elasticity; see, for example, [1,10,22,23,35,38,101] and references therein. In particular, second-gradient theories were developed for porous media for which surface effects play a crucial role [21,95,100]. For a gradient-type model of continua there exists not only surface tension, but also other stress-resultant and surface hyperstresses fields may appear naturally which may play an important role. Among them are edge-forces, surface double-forces, etc., see [24–26] for details. Let us also note that for the description of a complex inner microstructure shown in Fig. 1d, a more complex mathematical analysis may be required such as [81] for self-similar surfaces or as [87,88] for fractal-like solids.
The paper is organized as follows. Using the variational approach in Sect. 2, we formulate some models of surface elasticity. Here, we present the basic equations of the Gurtin–Murdoch model under infinitesimal deformations and briefly discuss Steigmann–Ogden models and further generalizations. Section 3 is devoted to effective properties of materials and structures considering surface phenomena.

sections.heading: 3 On effective properties of nanomaterials considering surface stresses
sections.text:
An analysis of the influence of surface stresses on the effective material properties is given in many works; see [7,27–30,67,68,115] and references therein. In particular, for nanostructured materials the following scaling lawwas discussed in [29,114]. Let F be somematerial property, i.e., Young’smodulus, temperature of melting. We denote by F(L) the value of F for a nanospecimen with characteristic size L and F(∞) for the material in the bulk. According to the scaling law [114], we have
F(L) F(∞) = 1 + lin L + O ( lin L )2 . (14)
Here, lin is a characteristic length, usually lin = 2 . . . 20 nm. Among examples of application of (14) is the size effect [18,62]. In what follows, we illustrate the scaling law considering tension of a rod with surface stresses.
3.1 Stiffness of a rod with surface effects

Let us consider the classic approach for which there is the thin layer of thickness δ with Young’s modulus Ef . In other words, we consider a composite rod which Young’s modulus near the lateral surface Ef differs from Young’s modulus E in the rod core.
For uniaxial tension of this non-homogeneous rod, the effective Young’s modulus can be calculated using the mixture rule [15],

Unlike (18), Eq. (21) predicts a more complicated behavior of E∗; for example, if Ef < E , then E∗ may be a non-monotonous function of R (see Fig. 4b).
As a result, we can conclude that the effective (apparent) material properties depend on the two following surface-related phenomena:
– the surface elastic moduli according to the Gurtin–Murdoch model [46] and/or – Young’s modulus of the bulk material in the vicinity of the surface and thickness of the surface layer.
Further, we consider the application of this model to nanoporous materials and to coatings with complex inner structure.

3.3 On effective properties of solids with coatings of complex inner structure
In Sect. 1 we described coatings with complex internal microstructure. Here we propose two steps of homogenization to model their surface properties. The main idea consists of replacing a thin coating by a material surface with effective properties and then using these properties for the determination of material properties at the macrolevel. So we propose to
1. find 2D effective (apparent) material properties; 2. then using these 2D properties to obtain 3D effective material properties as shown in the case of rods.
To illustrate the idea, let us discuss the effective properties for “foam-like” surfaces such as discussed in [19,37,64] (see Fig. 1c). An example of such coating is also given in Fig. 7.
Instead of a detailed description of geometry of these structures, simple idealized models of cell structures are often used in the mechanics of open-cell foams [9,41] (see Fig. 8). Let us also note that for this type of coatings v does not coincide with u. Indeed, here v corresponds to averaged through the thickness displacement of nanofoam or fibers. Thus, it includes shear deformations as well as thickness changes of the coating. sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
We discuss the influence of surface effects on effective (apparent) elastic stiffness properties of materials at the nanoscale. The interest to the investigation of the surface phenomena has recently grown with respect to the development of new nanostructured materials. We consider the Gurtin–Murdoch model of surface elasticity and classical approach based on the consideration of the thin surface layer whose mechanical properties differ from the bulk material. Within the framework of these models, we present the effective stiffness properties of nanosized rods.We have shown that the surface elasticitymakes a rod stiffer in comparisonwith the rodwithout surface stresses. The second approach shows that the effective stiffness of a rod with surface layers depends on the ratio of the elastic moduli of both the bulk and the surface materials. In particular, the nanoporous rod may be stiffer or softer than the solid rod.
Applying these two models, we discuss effective (apparent) properties of solids with imperfect surfaces/interfaces or coatings with inner microstructure. The effective elastic properties of these coatings highly depend on their microstructure. So the latter can be called surface or 2D metamaterials. We present the modifications of effective properties of coatings having the structure of a foam and of an array of ordered aligned nanofibers. The new approximated formulae for surface elastic moduli of these coatings are proposed.

metadata.abstractText: In the last years, the rapid increase in the technical capability to control and design materials at the nanoscale has pushed toward an intensive exploitation of new possibilities concerning optical, chemical, thermoelectrical and electronic applications. As a result, new materials have been developed to obtain specific physical properties and performances. In this general picture, it was natural that the attention toward mechanical characterization of the new structures was left, in a sense, behind. Anyway, once the theoretically designed objects proceed toward concrete manufacturing and applications, an accurate and general description of their mechanical properties becomes more and more scientifically relevant. The aim of the paper is therefore to discuss new methods and techniques for modeling the behavior of nanostructured materials considering surface/interface properties, which are responsible for the main differences between nanoand macroscale, and to determine their actual material properties at the macroscale. Our approach is intended to study the mechanical properties of materials taking into account surface properties including possible complex inner microstructure of surface coatings. We use the Gurtin–Murdoch model of surface elasticity. We consider the inner regular and irregular surface thin coatings (i.e., ordered or disordered nanofibers arrays) and present few examples of averaged 2D properties of them. Since the actual 2D properties depend not only on themechanical properties of fibers or other elements of a coating, but also on the interaction forces between them, the analysis also includes information on the geometry of the microstructure of the coating, on mechanical properties of elements and on interaction forces. Further we use the obtained 2D properties to derive the effective properties of solids and structures at the macroscale, such as the bending stiffness or Young’s modulus.
